pullrequest.title: Ramses frontend improvement  (min_level and max_level consistancy) + slight oct tree geometry change

content.raw:
As for why I have made these changes... ramses works in a 1-index format (so that the lowest resolved "level" is 1) as such that if max_level = 14, you will have up to 2^14 cells per dimension.

Which is fine, but the way the code is setup (e.g self.max_level = rheader['levelmax'] - self.min_level ) .. considering the min_level = rheader['levelmin'] - 1... the max level you are getting for a simulation resolving up to level 14, with a minimum level of 7,... 7 - 1 = 6... so your max level would be "9"

Now.. if you were to do a YTSphere with this, the YTSphereTooSmall exception will be raised... even though you have data that is resolved spatially beyond level 9.
content.html:
As for why I have made these changes... ramses works in a 1-index format (so that the lowest resolved "level" is 1) as such that if max_level = 14, you will have up to 2^14 cells per dimension.

Which is fine, but the way the code is setup (e.g self.max_level = rheader['levelmax'] - self.min_level ) .. considering the min_level = rheader['levelmin'] - 1... the max level you are getting for a simulation resolving up to level 14, with a minimum level of 7,... 7 - 1 = 6... so your max level would be "9"

Now.. if you were to do a YTSphere with this, the YTSphereTooSmall exception will be raised... even though you have data that is resolved spatially beyond level 9.

pullrequest.title: Ramses frontend improvement  (min_level and max_level consistancy) + slight oct tree geometry change

content.raw:
Hi Nathan, sorry I've been pretty bad at keeping up with this (my capacity to get sidetracked is pretty high). Yes, in RAMSES nomenclature a level refers to a grid cell of spatial length boxlen*2^(-level) refined level times from the top of the tree, so levelmax = 14 is an AMR cell of physical length boxlen*2^(-14), assuming no cosmological expansion, of course. For a simulation with no AMR, levelmin=levelmax. And then yeah, the hydro variables (density, pressure, etc) are stored in 2^ndim "octs" per cell.

I don't particularly know why there should be an issue with YT; I'm not particularly familiar with how YT treats octrees, unfortunately. I suppose that given YT uses inheritance from generic Octree objects and that the data in the derived objects is mixed up with the base classes' data, it makes sense to work exclusively in YT's definition of what a level is and have a couple of functions to convert between the two that are used whenever RAMSES data files are accessed. Apologies if this is already the case; like I said, I'm not that familiar with YT's octree classes so don't really know where the bugs would come from.

EDIT: Unsure how to stop the power-of symbol making the text italic, but the double asterisk notation boldfaces things, which is somewhat worse
content.html:
Hi Nathan, sorry I've been pretty bad at keeping up with this (my capacity to get sidetracked is pretty high). Yes, in RAMSES nomenclature a level refers to a grid cell of spatial length boxlen2^(-level) refined level times from the top of the tree, so levelmax = 14 is an AMR cell of physical length boxlen2^(-14), assuming no cosmological expansion, of course. For a simulation with no AMR, levelmin=levelmax. And then yeah, the hydro variables (density, pressure, etc) are stored in 2^ndim "octs" per cell.

I don't particularly know why there should be an issue with YT; I'm not particularly familiar with how YT treats octrees, unfortunately. I suppose that given YT uses inheritance from generic Octree objects and that the data in the derived objects is mixed up with the base classes' data, it makes sense to work exclusively in YT's definition of what a level is and have a couple of functions to convert between the two that are used whenever RAMSES data files are accessed. Apologies if this is already the case; like I said, I'm not that familiar with YT's octree classes so don't really know where the bugs would come from.

EDIT: Unsure how to stop the power-of symbol making the text italic, but the double asterisk notation boldfaces things, which is somewhat worse

Only outstanding issue with this pull request is the difference between .ds.index.max_level and .ds.max_level ... will poke it sometime in the next 24 hours... should not take too long to do.

Sam Geen. Yeah I agree (and thanks for your comments) using YT's definition of a level I agree with. So shifting whatever values RAMSES gives you to the YT equivalent is essential.. but so is being able to access all the highly resolved data too... might want to make a mention of it somewhere in the docs about octrees (i.e showing how YT handles it compared to RAMSES or another AMR code).. but that would just be my 2 cents.

content.raw:
Hi Matt.... The previous error I spoke about (2 comments above).. is caused by myself *not* importing YT in the interpreter.. calling objects from scripts... and then trying to use YT functionality (e.g getting a sphere object) without importing YT into the interpreter... I suspect this is a seperate error in it's own right.. and simply importing YT in the interpreter upon loading it up resolves the problem... those were all interpreter commands... I was trying to call an YT object from another script... and tried to interact with the YT fields without importing YT into the interpreter... basically something not sensible.

(for context.. I have some code that wraps around yt, pynbody and pymses)

Ben
content.html:
Hi Matt.... The previous error I spoke about (2 comments above).. is caused by myself not importing YT in the interpreter.. calling objects from scripts... and then trying to use YT functionality (e.g getting a sphere object) without importing YT into the interpreter... I suspect this is a seperate error in it's own right.. and simply importing YT in the interpreter upon loading it up resolves the problem... those were all interpreter commands... I was trying to call an YT object from another script... and tried to interact with the YT fields without importing YT into the interpreter... basically something not sensible.

(for context.. I have some code that wraps around yt, pynbody and pymses)

Ben

pullrequest.title: Ramses frontend improvement  (min_level and max_level consistancy) + slight oct tree geometry change

description:
I am going to be creating a series of updates/fixes to the YT frontend over the course of time whilst using YT to analyse my ramses simulation datasets.

Since ramses is "1-based" in terms of index hierarchy (looking around, I think FLASH is the same and maybe other fortran based AMR codes). I have made these updates to accommodate for this.

Main problem is with how it handles the max level and ds.index.get_smallest_dx()

I will be pushing more updates overtime, since I know there is a few bugs with some of the fields.

EDIT.. these changes ruin the octtree... going to look into it.

EDIT.. alter one thing and another problem occurs.

EDIT.. tested it on one unigrid run and two different multi-resolution runs... gives results that I would expect. We are good to go ahead with this PR

EDIT.. Also fixes my previous problems with rockstar too.

----------------------------------
As for why I have made these changes... ramses works in a 1-index format (so that the lowest resolved "level" is 1) as such that if max_level = 14, you will have up to 2^14 cells per dimension.

Which is fine, but the way the code is setup (e.g self.max_level = rheader['levelmax'] - self.min_level ) .. considering the min_level = rheader['levelmin'] - 1... the max level you are getting for a simulation resolving up to level 14, with a minimum level of 7,... 7 - 1 = 6... so your max level would be "9"

Now.. if you were to do a YTSphere with this, the YTSphereTooSmall exception will be raised... even though you have data that is resolved spatially beyond level 9.



Ben.
